layers.name: Post Fire Erosion Risk
layers.description: Wildfire disturbance generates bare soil that is then susceptible to erosion. The kf-factor determines the relative susceptibility to erosion. kf-Factor ranges from 0.02 for the least erodible soils to 0.64 for the most erodible. A simple model combining slope and kf-factor can create a classification of erosion hazard (USDA 1998). When combined with fire hazard, the areas where post-fire erosion is most likely to occur. This dataset was developed for the Data Atlas component of the Statewide Natural Resources Assessment for the 2020 New Mexico Forest Action Plan. The Atlas was prepared principally for use in spatial prioritization of resource protection and restoration strategies over 2020 – 2030 by the New Mexico Energy, Minerals and Natural Resources Department (EMNRD) Forestry Division (Forestry Division) and its partners. Within the Assessment framework, the dataset characterizes the Post-wildfire Flooding, Erosion and Debris Flow major threat factor.
layers.copyrightText: This dataset was developed for the Data Atlas by The Nature Conservancy (TNC) on behalf of the Forestry Division.
